data.title: Jonathan Parham
data.meta_description: Police2Peace unites departments and communities around programs that uplift and heal them.
data.text:
Louis Molina is a veteran public safety leader with experience serving across multiple local government jurisdictions in the three main pillars of the criminal justice system: policing, district attorney’s office and corrections.

Louis served as Chief of the Department of Public Safety for the City of Las Vegas, where he oversaw the city’s jail, deputy city marshal police force and Animal Protection Services. In 2018, Louis served as the first deputy commissioner for the Westchester County Department of Correction (DOC) where he led the Westchester County DOC successfully out of Department of Justice Federal oversight. Louis was credited with implementing significant reforms to the Westchester County jail and successfully obtained compliance with U.S. Department of Justice federal oversight agreement, leading to the successful conclusion by remedying constitutional violations at the county jail. Since his return to his hometown of New York City, Louis has served as Commissioner of New York City Department of Correction and as Assistant Deputy Mayor for Public Safety; he is currently serving as the Commissioner of the New York City Department of Citywide Administrative Services.

He began his career in law enforcement as a police officer in the New York City Police Department (NYPD) and after his service in the NYPD, Louis successfully went on to modernizing law enforcement systems through robust programming and community engagement, building staff capacity, and making strategic investments that improved conditions for staff, the community, and vulnerable and justice-involved persons. He has also built strong partnerships with faith-based and community leaders, and nonprofit organizations working with justice-involved individuals.

Louis thoroughly believes that in order to improve the criminal justice system, enhance the impact of social services and overall government operations, these systems need strategic disruption in how they are managed in order to address today’s challenges.

Louis Molina is a decorated veteran of the U.S. Marine Corps. He received a Bachelor of Arts degree in Philosophy from Chaminade University, a Master of Public Administration from Marist College School of Management, a Master of Arts degree in Human Rights Studies from Columbia University Graduate School of Arts and Sciences, and studied abroad at the University of Cambridge, United Kingdom. He was a U.S. Department of Justice/Office of Justice Programs National Institute of Justice Scholar and in 2020 received a scholarship from the Harvard Business School Fund for Leadership & Innovation in completion of his studies at Harvard Business School General Management Program.

Louis is excited to drive change and evolve government through stakeholder centered coaching of law enforcement and government leaders. He is an active member of the International Association of Chiefs of Police, American Society of Evidence Based Policing, New York State Sheriffs’ Association, and American Correctional Association.

Justin Insalaco’s career spans over two decades, marked by a profound commitment to transforming local and state government operations, focusing on community engagement strategies and evidence-based policing.

Beginning his journey as a Police Officer in New Jersey at the young age of 19 in 2009, Justin quickly developed a passion for fostering community relations. His dedication and innovative approach led him to spearhead major community policing initiatives, notably achieving the #1 ranking nationally for the National Night Out event.

Recognizing a significant technological shortfall in his agency just a year into his career, Justin embarked on a mission to bridge this gap. His efforts culminated in the creation of Guidant Systems on his own time. This venture revolutionized police work by introducing a mobile software suite, enabling officers to access and share critical information from any location seamlessly.

Beyond his police work, Justin has contributed significantly to various organizations. He served on the Board of WomenVotes, Inc., playing a pivotal role in developing a ride-sharing application for the 2016 election to facilitate voter turnout. In 2012, he lent his expertise as an Adviser to Crime Stoppers USA for Project ARC, a national initiative to reduce gun violence in K-12 schools. As Co-Chair of the Curtis Leadership Foundation, he collaborated with the National Police Athletic League to provide STEM and leadership education to underserved youth in Flint, East Cleveland, and 26 other cities.

Justin’s personal life reflects his professional ethos of unity and problem-solving. He is an avid hiker, enjoys leisurely walks with his dog, values quality time with his family, and finds joy in playing music. His multifaceted career and hobbies underscore his dedication to community betterment and personal fulfillment.

Chief John Carli (ret.) has 32 years of experience and is recognized as a progressive and innovative leader in law enforcement. Carli was appointed as Chief of Police of the Vacaville Police Department (California) in April of 2014, coming up through the ranks within his own agency. Carli retired in 2021, and shortly thereafter was elected as Mayor of his city in 2022. Carli is an internationally recognized speaker and public policy expert regarding homelessness, police legitimacy, and employee wellness.

His policing career started in 1989 where he spent his early years as a police officer patrolling the streets with his K9 partner, eventually serving as a field training officer and detective. While in Investigations, he was assigned to the Northern California Computer Crimes Task Force in Napa, California, investigating computer crimes and identity theft. Carli promoted through the ranks beginning in 2003 and, over the next several years, supervised patrol teams, the Critical Incident Negotiation Team, K9 Unit, Firearms Instructors, Police Technology, and the Office of Professional Standards.

As an outspoken advocate for the law enforcement profession, Carli’s most relevant work focuses on national best practices in policing, technology, public policy, and officer safety and wellness. In the summer of 2016, Chief Carli was summoned to the White House to meet with President Obama In the wake of national high profile policing events and civil unrest. Since then he has dedicated his time and efforts to improve the profession and implement change.

Carli was an early adopter of body-worn cameras to all officers as early as 2009. This gained national attention through the publishing of a department study on the issue of body-worn cameras and organizational trust, which was included in the US DOJ COPS report “Implementing a Body-worn Camera Program – Recommendations and Lessons Learned.”

John formed the Community Response Unit (CRU) using COPS funding, focusing on quality of life and homeless issues. Carli chairs the Vacaville Homeless Roundtable and is outspoken in coalescing community groups and the faith-based organizations to address social issues placed at the feet of law enforcement. His agency’s creative approach to reducing homelessness was highlighted during a Police Executive Research Forum (PERF) national town-hall meeting focusing on “The Police Response to Homelessness.”

Recognizing the gap between officers in crisis and the need for early prevention strategies, Carli embarked on implementing a radical culture shift to create psychological resiliency within first responders. John’s preventive approach to promoting this culture of wellness led to his development of the Cordico Law Enforcement Wellness App (Lexipol) that was highlighted at the Police Executive Research Forum (PERF) national town-hall summit, and is now recognized as the industry leader in wellness worldwide.

Under Carli’s leadership, the Vacaville Police Department (California) was recognized as the 2020 top agency in the nation by the National Law Enforcement Officers Memorial Foundation, receiving the “Destination Zero” Officer Safety and Wellness award.

Chief Carli continues to serve as an Executive Fellow with the National Policing Institute in Washington D.C., focusing on the continuous improvement within the policing profession. As chief, Carli represented the California Police Chief’s Association as the chair of the California Data Sharing Task Force, focusing on best practice strategies for law enforcement technology and information system sharing, and was a member of the California Attorney General’s Advisory Committee. John holds a Master of Science Degree in Strategic Leadership and is a graduate of the Police Executive Research Forum’s Senior Management Institute for Police, and was awarded the Executive Leadership Certificate by the California Department of Justice Commission on Peace Officer Standards and Training.

Chief Jeffrey Scott (ret.) is a nationally recognized leader in public safety leadership, with over 38 years, working with small to mid-sized agencies, including his time working for the Federal government at NASA. Jeffrey remains very active, even in retirement, as an executive leadership trainer and designer, and works with various agencies in general operations, strategic planning, operational readiness, accountability, quality improvement, accreditation, and risk mitigation strategies, just to name a few. His vast knowledge base and experience has made him a widely sought expert. Jeffrey’s experience does not just stop at Law Enforcement, but he is also a seasoned veteran of the Fire, EMS, Emergency Management and education arenas, and presently serves as the EMS Chief for a small, volunteer, rural EMS agency near his hometown, leading and transforming the agency to excellence in service for their community. Jeffrey is also the former Executive Director of the Ohio Peace Officer Training Commission, and he actively continues to use his experience and background to help law enforcement remain and be successful. Jeffrey is also the former President of the Ohio Chief’s of Police Association, and a graduate of the prestigious FBI National Academy, Class #265, as well as a former Board Director for the International Association of Property and Evidence.

Jeffrey was a very progressive Chief of Police, and was instrumental during his tenure, regaining public and agency level trust, implementing new community outreach initiatives, implementing new processes, policies and procedures for efficiency and accountability, new focus on best practices in evidence room management, bike patrol, strategic planning and leading the agency to accreditation.

Jeffrey is an accomplished author of many training articles in a wide variety of professional journals and publications and a former certified law enforcement trainer in Ohio and a recognized expert in many law enforcement topics, including his years as a crash reconstructionist. Jeffrey is a nationally recognized speaker on many law enforcement topics, including his stunning presentation call “Hot Topics in LE” and his new focus, training agencies on 1st Amendment and surviving the infamous “1st Amendment Audit,” and Change Management in LE.

Jeffrey is a graduate of Franklin University where he has received a bachelor’s degree in Public Safety Management and a master’s degree in Business Administration (MBA). Jeffrey is a Certified Law Enforcement Executive (CLEE) and a graduate of the prestigious FBI National Academy, Class #265, and the Ohio Police Executive Leadership College. Jeffrey is also a graduate of the MADD Leadership College and a former Board member of the Ohio Chapter, and the recipient of many honors and awards throughout his career, including a Distinguished Servant’s Award, the Heartland Hero Award and the NASA Chief’s Award for his leadership and on-scene command of a major NASA Center incident.

In his ‘spare time’ Jeffrey is a proud ‘cheer dad’ and #1 fan to his daughter, who is very active in competitive cheer and football/basketball cheer squads. He also serves as an ordained Pastor over a small rural congregation in Ohio’s Amish heartland.

Charles Husted is a retired Chief of Police from the Sedona Police Department. Before relocating to the City of Sedona, Charles retired as a Captain from the Sacramento Police Department after serving in his hometown for 31 years. He serves as the Director of Policing & Engagement for a national training and consulting company, Panthera7.

Additionally, in 2021, he was brought on as an Adjunct Administration of Justice Professor at Yavapai College, teaching courses in Community Policing, Criminal Investigations, and Corrections. Charles has become a certified American Heart Association Basic Life Support and HSI First Aid & CPR trainer because of his passion for helping others and making a positive difference in our society. He is a motivated and experienced leader with a heart for supporting and serving others.

Charles spent his thirty-four-year public safety career focused on community policing, collaborative problem solving, building strong partnerships, growing as a leader, and serving others. Early in his career, he learned that truly effective and sustainable outcomes don’t occur without working closely with the community, building trust, and being purposeful about involving stakeholders. He’s created, led, and participated in many working groups to identify and implement solutions using a systematic problem-solving model. Charles understands that innovation and idea generation comes from creating an environment where others are welcomed and feel safe to participate.

Charles was honored to lead various high-performing specialty teams: Gang Unit Investigations, School Resource Officers, and the Outreach & Engagement Unit. As an ancillary duty at the Sacramento Police Department, Charles also had the privilege of serving as a Crisis Negotiation Team Commander.

In addition to his years in executive management, Charles enhanced his professional skills and expertise through his training and experiences as a homicide and internal affairs investigator. He has a considerable background in investigating misconduct allegations against department personnel, including claims regarding severe criminal and other serious offenses. Additionally, he has managed and investigated numerous use of force, deadly force, and death in custody incidents.

Charles received his Bachelor of Business Administration degree in Organization Leadership, Management, and Communication from Corban University and is a master’s candidate in Organizational Leadership from American Public University. He is also a graduate of the Executive Leaders Program at the Naval Postgraduate School, the Senior Management Institute for Police executive leadership program, and the Federal Bureau of Investigation’s National Command Course. Charles has also completed Arizona State University’s Problem-Oriented Policing Leadership and Management program and California POST’s Executive Development Course. Charles received POST certifications in both California and Arizona, including being awarded his California POST Management certification in 2015.

Charles also has a broad training background in leadership, executive development, and bias awareness. He was selected and served as a national trainer for Procedural Justice and Police Legitimacy at the U.S. Department of Justice, COPS Office. Through education, experience, and training, Charles developed expertise in training and facilitating groups on many additional significant topics, including Kouzes & Posner’s “The Leadership Challenge,” Implicit Bias Awareness, Diversity & Racial Profiling, Police K-9 Program Management, COPS Office Safe Schools, Multi-Hazard Emergency Planning for Schools, and National Incident Management System.
